participants.participant: María García-Legaz Ponce, Head of Investor Relations
Santiago Fernández Valbuena, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to Telefónica's January to March 2009 results conference call.
I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. María García-Legaz, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, madam.
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Telefónica's conference call to discuss 2009 first quarter results. I am María García-Legaz, Head of Investor Relations.
Before proceeding, let me mention that this document contains financial information that has been prepared under International Financial Reporting Standards. This financial information is unaudited.

This presentation may contain announcements that constitute forward-looking statements, which are not guarantees of future performance and involves risks and uncertainties and that certain results may differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements as a result of various factors. We invite you to read the complete disclaimer included in the first page of the presentation, which you will find in our website. We encourage you to review our publicly available disclosure documents filed with the relevant securities market regulators. If you don't have a copy of the relevant press release and the slides, please contact Telefónica Investor Relations team in Madrid by dialing the following telephone number, 34-91-482-8700.
Now, let me turn the call over to our CFO, Mr. Santiago Fernández Valbuena, who will be leading this conference call.

Thank you, María and good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining Telefónica's 2009 First Quarter Results Conference Call. Today with me I have Julio Linares, our Chief Operating Officer, Guillermo Ansaldo, Head of Telefónica España, José María Álvarez-Pallete, Head of Telefónica Latinoamérica, and Matthew Key, Head of Telefónica Europe. During the Q &-A session you'll have the opportunity to ask questions directly to any of them.

In a more difficult economic environment, Telefónica has again posted very solid earnings, showing our focused strategy and our strength. As of today, we are delivering on the management priorities announced in February. We are pursuing major growth opportunities in our markets, which combines the benefits of our high geographic and business diversification, and our leadership in key markets, sometimes underappreciated, allow us to post industry-leading organic top line growth.

Revenue growth in Latin America continues to be very strong, but Telefónica Europe has shown an outstanding performance. We are also leveraging our scale and execution capabilities to actively manage OpEx and CapEx to further enhance efficiency and increase cash flow generation, and it's bearing fruits, as we continue to expand margin across geographies and operating cash flow growth well ahead of revenues.

And we are fully committed to have the very attractive shareholders remuneration, with growing dividends and share buyback programs tactically used. As we announced, in 2009 dividends per share will increase 15% year-on-year to €1.15 per share.

At the same time in the first quarter of 2009, we have recorded a strong 13% year-on-year increase in earnings per share, while we have reinforced our solid financial position, enhancing our debt maturities profile. The positive results reported in the first months of the year allow us to reiterate our 2009 guidance for all metrics – revenue, OIBDA, operating cash flow growth – and we do also confirm our previously stated EPS and free cash flow per share targets for 2010.

In slide number four, we show a summary of our first quarter earnings. In organic terms, we continued to post healthy growth rates, driven by Telefónica Latinoamérica, which contributed the most to the growth, and Telefónica Europe, which helped offset the lower contribution of Telefónica España. As a result, organic sales in the first three months of the year grew 2.8% year-on-year, while OIBDA growth rose 2.5%. OIBDA margins stood at 39.1%, showing the benefits of scale and higher efficiencies achieved. Operating income growth stood at 3.9% year-on-year, purely organic.

Turning to cash generation, organic operating cash flow grew by 4.5% year-on-year to reach €4.2 billion at the end of March. Please note it that the reported growth rates are negatively hit by ForEx, impacting major financial metrics by 1.3 to 4.7 percentage points. Net income amounted to €1.7 billion, showing an outstanding 10% versus the last year.

Organic revenue growth is driven by the continued expansion of our customer base. We ended March '09 with more than 261 million accesses at the Group level, or 4% above last year's figures. Growth rates posted by mobile, especially in mobile broadband, fixed broadband and pay TV are to be highlighted.

We are delivering very strong growth, not only in terms of cash, but also in terms of earnings per share. Reported basic earnings per share reached €0.37 per share, up around 13% annually. If we exclude the impact from purchase price allocations, earnings per share would have reached $0.14. And free cash flow per share totaled €0.28 in the first quarter of the year, recording a notable 57% year-on-year growth.

2009 guidance execution is presented in slide number six. Taking into account the seasonality of CapEx, we are fully on track to reach our growth targets. The guidance criteria consolidated year-on-year growth rates, revenues and OIBDA were 3.3% and 2.9% respectively, within the guidance ranges announced last February. CapEx up to March stood close to €1.3 billion.

As a result of the guidance criteria, operating cash flow growth reached 5%. However, growth will accelerate along the year as we have recorded lower investments in Q1 '08 to Telefónica O2 in Germany due to timing differences, higher investments in Q1 '09 in Vivo that should not be extrapolated for the full year, and the 3G licenses accounting in Q2 of '08 in Vivo.

Turning now to slide number seven, we saw that our strategy is adapted to market conditions in each of our geographies, and we are successfully executing our priorities in each region to deliver sound group results, combining the solid top line performance with an even higher cash flow generation. We are fully capturing our organic growth potential in those markets that keep growing, mainly in Latin America and Europe; while in countries like Spain, where trading conditions are more difficult, we are focused on increasing cash flow.

I'd like to highlight that operating cash flow organic growth exceeded by close to 2 percentage points the growth rate of sales on the back of our larger scale and the execution of our OpEx and CapEx efficiency measures. This is true not only for the Group as a whole, but for every single region of operations on a comparable basis.

In slide number eight, we show our ongoing focus to increase cash flow generation with an active management of OpEx and CapEx. A key message I want to pass is that we have flexibility to manage them without jeopardizing growth opportunities. Total Group CapEx decreased 4% year-on-year in the first quarter of '09, with reductions across most items, mainly due to the high investments already made in past years in GSM in Europe, and lower commercial activity in the traditional fixed-line business. However, we continue to invest in growth platforms, such as fixed and mobile broadband and pay TV. These investments represent 30% of our total CapEx year-to-date, and are increasing 10% year-on-year with an outstanding 36% rise in 3G CapEx versus last year's figure.

Two key data points show our flexibility to manage CapEx. First, 75% of the CapEx planned for 2009 is related to business transformation and growth projects, which could be managed and adapted to respond to changes in demand, competitive pressures, and the economic environment. Second, against the first quarter, CapEx committed was only 30% of our annual target.

We do also have a relatively high flexibility to retain control of our costs, as a significant part of our expenses could be manageable in the short term to respond to changes in demand. This ability is reflected in the 4% organic annual drop in total commercial costs on the back of lower handset subsidies, advertising and billing costs, and on the year-on-year decrease in interconnection costs, mainly driven by lower usage and tariffs in Spain.

As we explained in our previous conference calls, we are also developing global initiatives to further sharpen OpEx and CapEx efficiency at the Group level, leveraging of the advantages of the higher scale of our operations. The global initiatives already launched in the first quarter of '09 will generate more than €100 million savings for the full year, while we keep working across areas to accelerate the transformation of the company's operating model and obtain further efficiency gains.

Let's now review the performance of our operations, starting in Spain. In a more challenging environment, Telefónica España has been focused on maximizing operating cash flow and retaining value customers. Efficiency measures implemented have allowed to limit the OIBDA erosion, despite revenue pressure. Let me remark the increased OIBDA margin in wireless and flattish margins in wireline reflecting the royalty flexibility to adapt our cost base to the current situation.

Investments rationalization leveraging our integrated approach, have driven CapEx significantly down by 28%. Our OpEx and CapEx discipline have led to a strong performance in cash generation, with operating cash flow increasing by 0.2% year-on-year on a comparable basis in the first quarter, offsetting top line decline across businesses.

Turning now to slide number 10, let me summarize the major trends we are seeing on the top line. In a weaker economic scenario, we continue to see positive drivers. IT services are growing by almost 25% on contracts won over the quarter, while wireline data revenues are also showing a strong performance. Wireless data revenues keep growing by a notable 7%, boosted by sustained strong performance of connectivity revenues, up 50% in the first quarter.

On the negative side, the current environment is more noticeable in lower usage patterns across businesses, decrease in roaming in revenues as we have a lower number of visitors in our network, but also due to regulated price cuts. Additionally, the different phasing of wireless handset shipments to the channel are the signs of declining handset revenues. And we are also seeing a major impact from regulatory decisions. So as with the trend happening in other European markets, full ULL prices have been cut by 20% this year, and the PSTN monthly fee has remained unchanged versus 2008. In addition, we are being hit by the cumulative 17% cut in MTRs in the last 12 months. It's true that in terms of commercial activity during the quarter we have not led the growth of the margin, but we were able to do some revenue share and with some success I can say.

In wireless, we have seen over the last 12 months a positive gap between our customer revenue share and our access market share widening, and our estimate for the quarter is that this gap would finish the standard between four to five percentage points. In the wireline, we think that the gap should also have improved in the first quarter.

In slide number 11, we review the main KPIs of our Spanish operations. In Q1, we took a more rational commercial approach, which was not followed by other players in the market. With the slowing wireline retail Internet broadband market, that's another major European market, we posted over 9% growth in accesses, maintaining our leadership in the market with an estimated share of 56%.

The wireless business, with fast evolution of wireless data flat rates matching last year's figure. In the wireless business, we keep our focus on the value segment, extending our contract customer base ahead of the total. The mobile market continues to grow, albeit at a slower pace, the competition stays very compelling. In this environment, we kept under control churn at 1.9%, relatively unchanged versus last year's figure, with economic churn being well below this figure. ARPU reflected lower usage patterns, mainly in voice and in the residential segment and lower MTRs, though outgoing ARPU performed better as obtained by the solid data incoming ARPU. Data ARPU increased from 19% of total ARPU, growing five percentage points more than in January-March 2008, showing a very healthy performance.

Fixed telephony lines dropped 5.3% year-on-year, but still one of the best performances across main European markets, despite the tougher economic environment. It is worth mention that there is 53% of lines lost are now Telefónica wholesale lines, and therefore generate revenues for the company. Second, the ARPU of these customers is lower than the average ARPU, and most of the disconnections are single-play accesses; the remaining 47% of lines lost are related to the lower market growth and higher unbundler activity.

To finish up with Telefónica España's review, I'd like now to provide some more color on how we are managing our OpEx and CapEx base. Now we'll start things, we are doing a good job as our efficiency ratio shows, so the OpEx plus CapEx over revenues has gone down by 1.3 percentage points over the last 12 months. For the sake of comparison, we are using a 12 months rolling figure to avoid CapEx .

In the first quarter, CapEx was down 28% year-on-year led by lower investment in GSM. The fact that the deployment of the traditional routes has mostly halted as construction sector is closing, and broadband demand has slowed down and related investment has been adjusted accordingly, and we have adopted our fiber rollout to the current economic environment.

This, together with those initiatives, means that increasing CapEx efficiencies such as wirelines and wireless network integration, IT systems rationalization and also per unit cost reductions on delivering Group purchasing power and vendors adjusting prices to adapt to economic situation will continue benefiting us in the coming quarters. At the same time, we keep investing in growth platforms such as mobile data, without jeopardizing future growth prospects.

On the OpEx side, reductions came to 6% on a comparable basis due to commercial costs down 11%, handsets by 24% and interconnects 12%. Also, last year's head count reduction, together with lower CPI, has put less pressure on personnel costs.

As with CapEx, initiatives being deployed will also provide some OpEx lowering in the future. The energy efficiency and rationalization programs, logistics simplification mobile network sharing, among others.
Moving now to slide 13, to review on Latin American property, I would like to stress the very solid performance across most of our business, combining growth and profitability.

During the first quarter, customer organic growth across the region reached a healthy 13% year-over-year to surpass 159 million accesses, mainly driven by broadband and mobile services. The strong fundamentals of the business have led to an over 10% revenue growth ex-FX and 9% up to March in organic terms, supported by the further expansion of the mobile service revenues and Internet and pay TV sales.

OIBDA performed even better, posting a 14% organic growth. The OIBDA margin reached 38.5%, improving almost 2 percentage points versus March '08 in organic terms, driven by the strong advance in the mobile business, as we leveraged scale economics and further commercial efficiencies. Wireless OIBDA increased 6 percentage points year-on-year to 38.2%.
Improved profitability boosted operating cash flow generation, which, despite higher CapEx devoted to growth platforms, rose more than 4% year-on-year, even in organic terms.

Let me quickly sum up the evolution of our Latin American wireless businesses. Customer growth remained very strong in the quarter, registering double-digit growth rates in most operations in a region where the average wireless penetration has increased in the last 12 months, 12 percentage points to 83%. Further potential is still to be captured with the two largest markets, Brazil and Mexico, still lagging behind. Gross adds were lower than in the first quarter of 2008, but net adds in Q1 reached 1.3 million customers, as we capitalized on churn improvements year-on-year. Our strategy to stimulate usage to new commercial offerings led to a 17% increase in traffic However, ARPU performance was negatively impacted by the strong customer expansion and MTR cuts.

In terms of financials, I would like just to highlight that mobile sales posted a sound evolution, mainly explained by the remarkable growth of outgoing service revenues. Mobile data services, and in particular datacom activity and content SMSs continued to gain traction and already represents 17% of service revenues up to March, versus 14% last year. This area is a huge growth opportunity for us, and we will further exploit it along the year with a push on our 3G networks and mobile broadband offerings.

On slide 15, we show the events in the transformation of the wireline business. In the first quarter of 2009, broadband net adds were 142,000, to reach a total retail broadband access base of 6.2 million in March '09, or a 19% increase on an annual basis. The strong expansion was driven by our strategy to push our bundle and a deeper market segmentation through innovative propositions.

Pay TV to a triple-play solution is also key to limit the pressure on the traditional fixed-line business. These accesses advanced by over 30%, topping the 1.6 million mark at the end of March. As a result, Internet and pay TV revenues continued increasing their weight quarter-on-quarter, to top 20% of total wireline revenues; 2.6 percentage points more than a year ago, being the driver of wireline top line expansion.

In summary, our operations in Latin America continued to record a very healthy top line growth rate across most markets, despite the slowdown in some of the economies. In our scale, integrated management model and further efficiency gains continue to be approved with margin expansion across markets.

Let me outline the main topics across the key countries. In Mexico, with a market share north of 19.5%, service revenue continues growing ahead of customer growth and doubling our main competitor growth rate. And we have posted a strong increase in profitability, with a close to 10 percentage points margin expansion and an over 40% increase in local currency in operating cash flow.

In Brazil, Vivo has consolidated its leadership in a very competitive market, expanding its customer base by 19% in organic terms year-on-year, with service revenues growing ahead in organic terms and further margin advances. Telesp has reinforced its strategy of bundling and segmentation, fostering local flat rates and double- and triple-play offers with high broadband speeds in this first quarter, though Q1 performance was impacted by the introduction of a new call center law.

In Argentina, we have posted a very robust double-digit revenue growth, both in mobile and wireless, on the back of a strong bundling and on-net traffic strategy. In addition, operation leverage and further cost control measures drove OIBDA up by more than 30% year-on-year in local currency.

And finally, in Venezuela, the business is showing a very strong performance on all operating and international metrics. Profitability continues to improve, reaching margins over 52%, despite the double-digit growth in customers.

Turning now to slide 17, which shows that Telefónica Europe continued posting a strong financial performance in the first quarter, maintaining market momentum with a steady revenue growth in constant currency, while delivering year-on-year organic 12% growth in operating cash flow. It is worth mentioning the improved balance in our European business portfolio, particularly Germany, and the increase in revenue contribution from DSL activities.

Total customer base was up 9% to 47 million, highlighting an exceptional performance in the wireless contract segment through some propositions around flat rates, SIM-only, mobile broadband as well as successful retention of business across markets. Ongoing focus on efficiency programs and flexible management of CapEx are also key to adapt business to an increasingly tough operating environment.

In the U.K., Telefónica O2 business, again, outperformed in a slower market. After adding close to 300,000 contract customers at the end of March, contract customers made up 43% of the mobile base on the back of healthy gross adds and market-leading contract churn rate at 1.2%. The combination of O2's range of innovative propositions and its leadership in customer satisfaction across all segments continued to drive market share gain.

Revenue growth remains solid at 7% year-over-year in local currency, driven by the 5.2% rise in wireless service revenues. The increased number of mobile broadband connections and continued success of high-end phones, such as the BlackBerry and the iPhone, running non-peer, peer-to-peer, SMS data revenue year-over-year growth of 42%. Obviously, the voice ARPU declined as it reflects the current trading environment.

The company was able to keep margins in the quarter at 24%, leveraging on efficiency optimization of customer investment costs, continued operational efficiencies in non-commercial costs, and improved contribution from the DSL business that helped the business maintaining momentum in the market.

On slide number 19, we show that Telefónica O2 Germany is on track to realizing its full potential in Europe's largest telco market. The business continued to deliver profitable growth in the quarter, with total revenues increasing 3.6% year-on-year on sustained mobile business and fixed broadband performances. A significant 38% growth in contract net adds quarter-on-quarter already shows the benefit from the ongoing investment in our own network build out and increased distribution channels.

The recent introduction of the O2 one proposition in the German market based on the clear, simple and transparent tariff structure, will start to drive momentum in the German market. A clear outcome from building foundations of the business is the 24% year-on-year growth in OIBDA and 23% margin in the first quarter of 2009.

Turning now to our financial profile, we show that it remains steady. In the first quarter, our debt has been reduced by €500 million and our debt ratios stand below two times OIBDA or just above it when we include other cash commitments.

In the first quarter, we have further improved our financial profile as of both in the short and in the long-term. We have raised €3 billion from the bond market for pre-financing debt maturing in Telefónica SA in 2009, and we have extended €4 billion of our syndicated facility maturing 2011, where we have 50% one year later and 50% two years later. As such, our existing cash balance exceeds gross maturities for the remainder of 2009. Our average debt life exceeds 6.4 years in March '09, registering a 0.5 year increase, thanks to our financing activities. Our financial expenses stay at 5.95% of our average total debt of €45.1 billion. As 25% of our debt remained exposed to floating risk, we expect a decreasing trend as new lower rate fixings gradually replace the old ones.

To sum up, we continue to post strong results, capitalizing on our highly diversified asset portfolio and delivering on the management priorities that we announced for 2009. First, we are capturing growth opportunities in our markets, allowing us to post benchmark organic growth rates. Second, we increased our strong cash flow generation across regions. Third, the 2009 dividend per share will increase 15% against the fiscal year of 2008. In addition, we have a sound financial position and we have posted double-digit earnings per share growth.
Finally, I would like to reiterate our confidence to deliver again on our commitment. We are fully on track to meet 2009 guidance and we do confirm our 2010 EPS and free cash flow per share targets.
Thanks very much for your attention, and now we are ready to take your questions.
.Our first question comes from the line Mathieu Robilliard from Exane. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. I have two questions, please. First, with regards to Telesp, the trends deteriorated quite a bit versus Q4, so obviously positive revenue growth. But we note that in traffic, the turns are much worse than 2008. So I was wondering if you could give us a bit of color here on this quarter and then normally versus 2008, or is this the trend we should expect for this year?

And second, about your performance in Venezuela, I note that total traffic is up 7%, yet ARPU is up 22%. So I was wondering if the increase in ARPU was merely due to the fact that you are able to pass the high inflation in the country to your customers, or is there anything else in terms of new product adoptions et cetera? Thank you.

Good afternoon and thanks for the question. On Telesp, I would like to outline that bulk of the performance has been driven by the impact that we have been having on the new law on call centers that has been driving us to focus our main activity in addressing quality concerns and sustaining the number of lines. And therefore, we have been closing some of the commercial activity till those problems were fixed. It is true that this new call center law was issued in December, but the main impacts have been flowing in January and February.

On top of that, it is true that we have been forced to adopt the commercial offer in order to focus on new products and bundles. But mainly, the impact in Telesp in the first quarter is driven by this fact that we have been focusing our main activity in addressing the impacts of these new call center law.

It is also true that the figures of last year were impacted by the incorporation and therefore growth last year appears to be higher than the organic growth. But mainly the impact has been adverse. And therefore, we are focusing all our efforts in addressing the situation and we are confident that the situation will be improving gradually in the next quarters. On top of that, Brazil is extending some kind of cooperation in terms of industrial activity, in terms of credit activity, so we do think that the Brazilian market can offer some additional possibilities in the next quarters.

In Venezuela, we have several effects. It is true that we have been increasing tariffs, but it is also true that we have been focusing on the mobile traffic, on-net traffic and contract customers. It is also true that the handset activity in Venezuela in different concentrations has also been very high and therefore there are several effects that are mixed in Venezuela, not only the factor of inflation. We are also driving the quality of our customers and that way, you will see that our -share of revenues is higher than the share that we have now – on market share on customers. So I think that there are several effects that are being mixing in Venezuela.
Thank you.
Next question please.
Your next question comes from the line of Michelle Collett from Cazenove. Please go ahead.

Hi there. Three questions please. Firstly, the CapEx level in Spain is very low this quarter; I wondered whether that was sustainable going forward? And secondly, you mentioned the roaming effect and what that does to service revenues. Can you perhaps quantify how much of the revenues are roaming, and also perhaps give us an indication of what sort effect you'd expect in later quarters? Presumably it's got a greater effect in Q2 and Q3. And then finally, performance in Colombia looks a touch like, I think you've probably lost in subscriber markets there. Can you perhaps talk to us about what's happened there? Thanks.

Okay. This is Guillermo Ansaldo. Regarding your questions in CapEx, yes it is a low level but has several levers that explain that levels. First, we are reducing CapEx on 2G and we are focusing on 3G; that's a strategic move and that will be sustained. Second, the lower level of commercial activity in some CapEx-intensive accesses, like broadband or pay TV, is a bad news on the revenue side, but on the CapEx side, we're able to obviously save money on that front. Obviously also third, we are adapting the fiber rollout to the current environment: that means that whenever we have a case where we see a positive NPV and a very short repayment period, we will do it. But otherwise we will postpone it, or we'll think it for future times.

So some of these – and also, sorry, another very strong factor is that we are getting better prices on the purchasing vendor side, profiting from the scale of the Group and our industry alliances. So that's our very sustainable reasons. Obviously, I hope that trading conditions improve and I will be able to spend more money on the commercial side. But and also – but quarter-by-quarter we have some seasonality in the way we spend the money. But the savings due to model our spending to the commercial activity is something that is very natural and the purchasing savings and the scale savings that will be there to remain.

Regarding your roaming questions, let me see if I get it right, you want the numbers. Let me give you all the numbers and then see if I answer your question but, total service revenues – service revenues is revenues without handset revenues, is 1,900; 21 is the table in the information we published. Out of that, 29 million is roaming in, and that has a decrease of 32%, and that's based on two factors. One is approximately a 7% decrease in the visitors, 7.7 decrease in the visitors, and also there is a decrease in the traffic linked to those visitors of 5.9%, and the rest is price reduction.
So if price reduction and some of the savings are in line also with expense reduction related to roaming costs, but roughly 29 millions in the quarter for roaming in.
Okay. I guess I was trying to get is that going to be a greater impact in Q2 and Q3, if you have the same trend?
Well, it's 29 millions out of almost 2,000, not 1,921.
Okay.

So that's basically the level of impact that we're going to get. And on the OIBDA level, remember that on the roaming expense, all the price reductions we also get some reduction on volume reduction on the expense, so it's not that relevant. I am much more concerned on the customer revenues than on the roaming.
Yeah, okay.

Taking your question about Colombia wireless, it is true that credit rates has been increasing in this quarter because we have been changing that part of the customer base after the Christmas campaign, which is I would say normal. I know our main competitor did the same in the same period. It is true that on the contract side, we need to replace the offer and we are focusing on that on the pre price, while we have, I would say, an attractive offer on the market, we need to strengthen our commercial distribution networking in Colombia, and that's what we are doing.

But let me stress that in the same time we are highly focusing on profitability. We have been reducing handset subsidies and we have been much more focused on profitability on our traffic campaigns and as a result of that, let me stress that OIBDA has increased by 28%, and that operating cash flow has been increased by roughly 70%. So it's a need of looking for more profitability and replacing and refocusing our commercial campaigns there.
Okay. Great. Thank you.
Next question, please.
The next question comes from Jesus Romero from Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Thank you. Guillermo, I don't know if you can provide us a bit more detail on traffic in Spain in mobile. I know you're not reporting MoU anymore, but, then if you can give us some thoughts of what the numbers look like? And then a question on Venezuela: what is the cash position right now at the end of Q1? And what can you do to get that money out, if there is anything you can do? Thank you.

Well, this is also Guillermo. Regarding traffic in Spain in the mobile business, two comments. First, you see service revenues are decreasing but the gap is half the gap of the total revenues because of the handset sales. But focusing on client revenues, roughly again 75% is ARPU reduction and 25% is less access growth. And in ARPU reduction, obviously, we are seeing a modest deceleration, particularly in prepaid. Postpaid is deteriorating the same way as in the fourth quarter, but prepaid is the one that has changed shape in this quarter.

So roughly in terms of MoU, to give you the actual number, we are decreasing 6% total MoU minutes. And again, if you take away the things that we usually take away, like the data only SIMs and campaigns so we can compare in the same level, that number goes down to, I think, 4.4. So basically, it's a 6% reduction in MoUs and 4.4 reduction if you take away these two effects. Again, it's much more focused, the change in trend, in prepaid. So the top-ups in the quarter, particularly in March, were lower than expected and obvious that was hit in the MoU and obviously hit in the ARPU.

Jesus, this is Santiago. And on terms of the cash position in Venezuela, as you know, Venezuela operates under currency controls, so you have to ask a permission to the local currency agency to repatriate dividends or other payments. Currently, we have asked for the 2006 dividends to be repatriated. And on top of that, we have a cash position, which is roughly equivalent to the dividends that we would expect to claim to go home for 2007 and 2008. The net cash position is roughly equivalent to $2 billion as of present, which is also roughly the amount that the two dividends – or the two net profit figures for 2007 and 2008 – should look like.
And if I could follow up, the black market rate of the bolivar is what eight bolivares per euro right now against official price of three more or less?

Well, it's not a black market; it's actually a so-called parallel currency market and it's been going from four to eight, depending on when you look at it. Truthfully, the result is under inflationary pressures and that is no secret, but it's anybody's guess exactly to where the currency should be aligned, if the market were to be first opened. What we can say, what we have been saying all along, is these attentions are significant, that so far we have been repatriating at the official exchange rate, which . And while the cash is there, it is not sitting idle, it is earning interest. And so this has a mitigating impact on the time delay relative to the times when we request the repatriation.
Okay. Thank you.
Next question, please.
Our next question comes from the line of Terence Sinclair from Citi. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Could I ask you two questions. First of all, in Spain, I am keen to know whether the slowdown, or shrinkage rather, got worse during the quarter, or whether the ex-rate, excess rate, from the quarter was similar to the beginning of the quarter. Secondly, I don't really understand why Argentina did so well from a profit point of view, given the slowdown in revenue growth, and I wonder if I could ask you to link the answer to the level of inflation in Argentina. What was the real ex-inflation rate of sales and profit growth, please?
Hey, Terry, this is Guillermo Ansaldo. If I understood correctly your question, you want to know the shape of the slowdown across the quarter?
Right.

March was worse than the first two months in terms of traffic, in terms of all buying patterns and consumer patterns. Good news is that April is better than March, so we still trying to understand what happens in the minds of consumers. But March was a very low month for trading in Spain in general, and also in our business. April was better than March in some categories, much better; in some, slightly better. But it's a different month, so we'll see. But March was the worst month in the three months of the quarter.
Guillermo, could I just follow up? I was unclear whether you claiming that you'd taken or lost revenue share during the quarter?

Well, two things. First, in the quarter, we have an estimation because we don't have all the companies publishing their results. So, for example, up to now, if I'm correct, Vodafone has not published their results, so we do estimation – we do a lagging quarter type of estimation.
